Genesis shares similar themes with this literature but provides a unique monotheistic perspective
q70.explanation: Genesis shares similar themes with ancient Near Eastern literature (like Babylonian creation poem Enuma Elish, Gilgamesh flood narrative): creation, flood, heroes. q71.question: How does understanding the Honor-Shame Culture of the first-century Mediterranean world help in understanding the New Testament?

Understanding honor-shame culture helps explain Jesus' parables, Paul's rhetoric, and early believers' behavior
Only guilt culture influences the New Testament
q71.explanation: The first century was an honor-shame culture (collectivist, valuing public opinion), not modern Western guilt culture (individualist, valuing inner conscience). deepDive.title: Honor-Shame Culture and New Testament Interpretation
deepDive.content: Honor-shame culture characteristics: 1) Collective identity (family/group honor); 2) Public reputation crucial; 3) Challenge-response pattern (like Pharisees challenging Jesus); 4) Patron-client relationships (patronage); 5) Limited good perspective (zero-sum game, others' gain is my loss). q72.question: What does 'Form Criticism' explore in biblical studies?
options: The literary aesthetics of the Bible
The printing history of the Bible

The text format of the Bible

deepDive.content: Form criticism steps: 1) Identify literary forms (Gattungen)â€”miracle stories, conflict stories, parables, sayings, passion narrative, etc.; 2) Analyze structural characteristics of forms; 3) Reconstruct 'life setting' (Sitz im Leben)â€”in what early church context was this form used (worship, teaching, mission, debate); 4) Trace tradition development. q73.question: How does 'Redaction Criticism' differ from 'Form Criticism'?
options: Redaction criticism only concerns grammatical errors

Redaction criticism studies how editors selected and arranged material to convey theological messages
q73.explanation: Redaction criticism (developed mid-20th century) studies Gospel writers' roles as theologians and editors. For example, how Matthew arranged Jesus' teachings into five major discourses, or how Luke emphasized Jesus' concern for the marginalized.

journalPrompt.content: Redaction criticism reminds us that Gospel writers were not mechanical scribes, but theologians who, under the Spirit's guidance, consciously shaped the message for specific readers. Inspiration does not erase human personality.

deepDive.title: Application of Redaction Criticism
deepDive.content: Redaction criticism method: 1) Compare parallel passages in Synoptic Gospels; 2) Analyze authors' additions, omissions, arrangements; 3) Identify authors' theological themes and emphases. Examples: 1) Matthew's five major discourses (chs 5-7, 10, 13, 18, 24-25) echo the Pentateuch, showing Jesus as the new Moses; 2) Luke-Acts' journey theme (Luke 9:51 'set his face toward Jerusalem,' Acts 1:8 'to the ends of the earth'); 3) John's 'I am' declarations and 'believe' verb (John 20:30-31). Contribution: appreciating each Gospel writer's unique theological perspective. Limitation: should not assume editing = fabrication; authors still constrained by historical events.

q74.question: What is the primary concern of Feminist Biblical Criticism?
options: Only studying texts by female authors
Proving the Bible is against women
Examining gender bias in biblical texts and interpretation, restoring women's voices and experiences
q74.explanation: Feminist biblical criticism (developed late 20th century) focuses on: 1) Exposing patriarchal interpretive traditions; 2) Re-reading marginalized women's stories (like Hannah, Ruth, Esther, Mary, Mary Magdalene); 3) Challenging oppressive textual applications; 4) Advocating just and equal interpretation. The goal is not to reject the Bible, but to read it more faithfully.

journalPrompt.title: Women in the Bible
journalPrompt.content: The Bible records many faithful women: Deborah led Israel, Ruth showed steadfastness, Esther saved her people, Mary bore the Savior, Mary Magdalene was the first resurrection witness. God values women.

deepDive.title: Methods and Controversies of Feminist Interpretation
deepDive.content: Feminist interpretation methods: 1) Deconstructive readingâ€”exposing patriarchal ideology; 2) Reconstructive readingâ€”restoring women's history and contributions; 3) Creative readingâ€”imagining women characters' untold stories; 4) Normative readingâ€”establishing liberating and just interpretive principles. Focus texts: Gen 2-3 (Eve), Judg 4-5 (Deborah), Prov 31 (virtuous woman), Luke 1-2 (Mary and Elizabeth), Rom 16 (deacon Phoebe), 1 Cor 11 and 14 (women in church), Gal 3:28 (unity in Christ), Eph 5 (husband-wife relationship), 1 Tim 2 (women teaching). Controversy: radicals view the Bible as a patriarchal document needing critique; evangelical feminists view the Bible as a liberating document that has been misused.

q75.question: What issues does Postcolonial Biblical Criticism explore?
options: Examining empire power dynamics in biblical texts and how the Bible was used for colonization and decolonization
q75.explanation: Postcolonial criticism (developed late 20th century) explores: 1) Empires in biblical texts (Egypt, Assyria, Babylon, Persia, Rome); 2) Ethical issues of Canaanite conquest; 3) How the Bible was used by colonizers to justify oppression; 4) How the colonized re-read the Bible seeking liberation (like Latin American liberation theology). The goal is to decolonize interpretation, letting marginalized voices be heard.

journalPrompt.title: Voices from the Margins
journalPrompt.content: The Bible itself is the literature of the oppressed: Hebrew slaves escaping Egypt, exiles lamenting in Babylon, the persecuted church in the Roman Empire. God stands with the weak.

deepDive.title: Perspectives of Postcolonial Interpretation
deepDive.content: Postcolonial criticism focuses on: 1) Empire critique in the Bibleâ€”Exodus' critique of Pharaoh, Daniel's critique of Babylon/Persia, Revelation's critique of Rome ('great Babylon'); 2) Problematic textsâ€”conquest of Canaan (Josh 1-12), the ethics of 'ban' (herem); 3) Colonial historyâ€”how Western missionaries used the Bible to support colonialism ('civilizing mission'), while also bringing education and healthcare; 4) Decolonizing interpretationâ€”how African, Asian, Latin American theologians read the Bible from indigenous contexts. Contribution: revealing interpretive cultural and power factors. Challenge: avoiding simplification (the Bible has both empire critique and God-authorized Canaan conquest narratives); balancing special revelation and universal justice.
